verses.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच
ये शास्त्र-विधिम् उत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः ।
तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वम् आहो रजस् तमः ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ |
teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: Those who worship (yajante) with faith (śraddhayānvitāḥ) but have abandoned scriptural injunction (śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya) — what is their standing (niṣṭhā), O Krishna? Is it sattva, rajas, or tamas?

word_breakdown.meaning: scriptural injunction / the rule of scripture

commentary.dadaji: Arjuna's question here is one of the most practically relevant in the entire Gita. He has just heard Krishna say in Chapter 16 that scripture is the authority for determining right and wrong action. Now he asks: what about the countless sincere devotees across all traditions who worship from the heart but do not follow any formal scriptural system? Is their devotion worthless? Krishna's answer, unfolding across this entire chapter, is deeply compassionate — faith is real, and its quality is shaped by the nature (svabhāva) of the seeker. No sincere worship is without its fruit or standing.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This question bridges the end of Chapter 16, which concluded that scripture (śāstra) is the guide for determining proper action, with the practical reality that many people worship sincerely without following specific scriptural rules. Arjuna is not challenging the importance of scripture but rather asking where such heartfelt, unstudied devotion stands in the cosmic order. The three guṇas — sattva, rajas, and tamas — are the lens Krishna will use to answer. Every act of faith, worship, and devotion bears the stamp of the predominant guṇa in the devotee's nature.
commentary.yogananda: Arjuna's inquiry reflects a universal human experience: the sincere seeker who prays, worships, or meditates without formal religious training. Paramahansa Yogananda taught that God responds to the quality of devotion in the heart, not merely to ritual correctness. Yet Krishna's forthcoming answer shows that the guṇic makeup of the devotee shapes the very character of their faith — its object, its depth, and its fruit. The chapter is a compassionate mapping of where different types of faith lead, guiding the seeker toward the sāttvika path that ultimately elevates consciousness toward liberation.
commentary.goyandka: Arjuna's question arises from genuine concern for ordinary devotees who have deep faith but no formal scriptural grounding. Śrī Goyandka notes that this verse carries the inquiry: is natural, innate faith acceptable to God even without śāstra? Krishna's answer affirms that faith is never formless — it always takes a shape determined by one's intrinsic nature (svabhāva). The quality of that faith, whether sāttvika, rājasī, or tāmasī, determines what one worships, how one lives, and what results one obtains. The scriptures serve as a corrective and elevating guide precisely because natural faith, left ungoverned, may follow the lower guṇas.

verses.sanskrit:
श्री भगवान् उवाच
त्रि-विधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभाव-जा ।
सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
tri-vidhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāva-jā |
sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śṛṇu ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: The faith of embodied beings (dehināṃ) is threefold, born of one's own nature (svabhāva-jā) — sāttvikī, rājasī, and tāmasī. Hear about this from Me.

word_breakdown.meaning: of embodied beings / of those with bodies
born of one's own nature (svabhāva = inherent nature, jā = born)
of the nature of sattva / pure faith
of the nature of rajas / passionate faith
of the nature of tamas / inert/dark faith

commentary.dadaji: Krishna's opening answer is remarkably non-judgmental. He does not say that people without scriptural guidance have no valid faith — He says their faith is real but takes the color of their svabhāva, their inherent nature shaped by accumulated karma and guṇas. 'Svabhāva-jā' is the key: faith is not imposed from outside but arises organically from within. The three forms of faith — sāttvikī, rājasī, tāmasī — are not moral condemnations but accurate descriptions of where each person stands on their journey. Krishna's compassion lies in His recognition that even tamasic faith is faith, and it has its own progression.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'svabhāva-jā' deserves deep contemplation. Svabhāva literally means 'one's own being' or 'inherent nature.' Faith is not acquired but emerges from what one already IS — the accumulated tendencies of countless lifetimes crystallized into one's current guṇic constitution. Swami Sarvapriyananda emphasizes that this verse does not prescribe but describes: Krishna is giving us a map of the territory of human faith. Understanding which type of faith predominates in oneself is itself a form of self-knowledge — and self-knowledge is the beginning of transformation.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that svabhāva — one's intrinsic nature — is the deposit of all past actions and thoughts, one's karmic inheritance. Faith, being the deepest orientation of the soul, naturally reflects this inheritance. The sāttvika person's faith is clear, directed toward light; the rājasika person's faith is intense but scattered toward worldly power and pleasure; the tāmasika person's faith is clouded and directed toward forces of inertia and darkness. Yet Yogananda would note that all three are seeds of the same divine impulse — the soul's search for its source — and all can be elevated through sādhana and grace.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka notes that Krishna uses the word 'śṛṇu' — 'hear' — signaling that what follows is important teaching requiring attentive listening. The fact that faith is 'svabhāva-jā,' born of nature, explains why mere external instruction is often insufficient to transform people: their faith runs deep in their constitution. This is why the Gita's prescription is not just intellectual knowledge but the gradual purification of one's svabhāva through sattvic action, worship, food, and austerity — which are the very topics of this chapter. Changing one's guṇic constitution changes the quality of one's faith and, therefore, of one's entire life.

verses.sanskrit:
सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत ।
श्रद्धा-मयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्-छ्रद्धः स एव सः ॥
verses.transliteration:
sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata |
śraddhā-mayo'yaṃ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
verses.translation: The faith of each person is in accordance with their essential nature (sattvānurūpā), O Bhārata. This person is made of faith (śraddhā-mayaḥ); whatever one has faith in — that indeed one IS (yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: in accordance with one's sattva / nature (sattva + anurūpā = conforming to)
made of faith / constituted by faith

commentary.dadaji: This is one of the most philosophically charged verses in the Gita. 'Yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ' — whatever one has deepest faith in, that one is. Faith is not a belief one holds; it is a reality one has become. If your deepest faith is in material pleasure, you have become a materialist at the level of being. If your deepest faith is in God, you are becoming divine. Dadaji often pointed to this verse as the basis for understanding why transformation must be at the level of śraddhā — one's most fundamental conviction — not merely at the level of behavior or thought. Deepest faith reshapes identity.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda highlights 'śraddhā-mayo'yaṃ puruṣaḥ' as one of the Gita's most penetrating psychological insights: the human being is not primarily a thinking animal or a desiring animal, but a faith-animal — constituted by what one fundamentally trusts, values, and believes to be real. Modern psychology speaks of core beliefs and deep values; the Gita goes deeper, pointing to śraddhā as the very substance of personhood. 'Yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ' is not just descriptive but prescriptive: to change who you are, change what you have faith in.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda understood this verse as the scriptural basis for the transformative power of devotion. If you habitually hold the thought and feeling 'I am a divine child of God, and God alone is real,' that śraddhā progressively reshapes your entire being. Conversely, habitual faith in limitation, fear, and material identity keeps one bound. Yogananda's teaching of affirmations and meditation is precisely this: consciously redirecting śraddhā toward the divine so that, according to Krishna's law, one becomes what one consistently has faith in. This verse is the metaphysical root of all spiritual practice.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka explains that 'sattva' in 'sattvānurūpā' refers not just to the guṇa sattva but to one's inner being or essential nature (antaḥkaraṇa). Faith mirrors the inner nature, and inner nature is itself built from accumulated habits of thought, feeling, and action. The statement 'yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ' is both a warning and an invitation: a warning because misplaced faith degrades the soul, and an invitation because rightly placed faith — in God, in righteousness, in liberation — elevates and ultimately transforms the entire being. Śraddhā in the Lord is the direct path to becoming like the Lord.

verses.sanskrit:
यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान् यक्ष-रक्षांसि राजसाः ।
प्रेतान् भूत-गणांश् चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṃsi rājasāḥ |
pretān bhūta-gaṇāṃś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ ||
verses.translation: The sattvic worship the gods (devān); the rajasic worship yakṣas and rākṣasas; others — the tamasic — worship the departed (pretān) and hosts of elementals/spirits (bhūta-gaṇān).

word_breakdown.meaning: the sattvic ones / those of sattvic nature
yakṣas and rākṣasas (semi-divine power-beings and demons)
the rajasic ones / those of rajasic nature
the departed / ghosts / spirits of the dead
hosts of spirits / groups of elemental beings
the tamasic people / people of tamasic nature

commentary.dadaji: This verse maps the three levels of worship onto three planes of reality. Sattvic worshippers direct their faith upward — toward the devas, the luminous cosmic forces that uphold dharma and light. Rajasic worshippers seek power and wealth through propitiation of yakṣas (nature-spirits associated with wealth) and rākṣasas (forces of aggression and self-assertion). Tamasic worshippers, driven by fear and attachment to the dead, propitiate pretas and bhūta-gaṇas. The quality of one's worship reveals the quality of one's soul. One does not need to look at what someone professes to believe — watch what they actually sacrifice their time, energy, and resources upon: that is their true worship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that yakṣas in Indian tradition are associated with worldly wealth (Kubera, the god of wealth, is their king), and rākṣasas with raw power and dominance. Rajasic religion, then, is essentially transactional and power-oriented: worship in order to gain wealth, status, victory over enemies. This is very much alive in contemporary religious practice — prayers and rituals performed to gain material advantage. Tamasic worship of pretas and bhūtas reflects religion rooted in fear — fear of the dead, fear of spirits — which motivates propitiatory rites. Only sattvic worship is genuinely uplifting, oriented toward the luminous and the transcendent.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda saw this verse as a teaching about where one's attention habitually goes. The 'devas' are not merely mythological beings but principles of light, truth, and cosmic order — the sattvic person worships these principles in their outer religious life and in their inner life of meditation. The rajasic person, though perhaps performing religious rituals, is inwardly worshipping their own ambitions, desires for power, and competitive ego. The tamasic person is bound by dread of dark forces and ancestral obligations rooted in fear rather than love. True worship, Yogananda taught, is the complete offering of one's consciousness to the Divine.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka points out that this classification is not about which religion one belongs to but about the inner attitude underlying any religious practice. A person in any tradition can worship with sattvic intent — directed toward the highest light and truth — or with rajasic intent (seeking material gain through religious means), or with tamasic intent (driven by superstition and fear). The Gita is not condemning specific religious communities but discerning the inner quality of devotion. The implication is clear: one should examine one's own worship and ask, 'Am I approaching God to give, to surrender, and to love — or to get something for myself?'

verses.sanskrit:
अशास्त्र-विहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः ।
दम्भाहङ्कार-संयुक्ताः काम-राग-बलान्विताः ॥
verses.transliteration:
aśāstra-vihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ |
dambhāhaṅkāra-saṃyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ ||
verses.translation: Those who practice terrible (ghora) austerities not enjoined by scripture (aśāstra-vihitam), combined with ostentation (dambha) and ego (ahaṅkāra), and impelled by desire (kāma), passion (rāga), and force (bala)...

word_breakdown.meaning: not sanctioned by scripture (a = not, śāstra = scripture, vihitam = enjoined/prescribed)

commentary.dadaji: This verse begins a two-verse description (completed in verse 6) of perhaps the most dangerous form of misguided spirituality: extreme asceticism motivated not by love of God or genuine renunciation, but by ego, desire for recognition, and passionate will. 'Dambha' is spiritual vanity — performing austerities to be seen, to build a reputation as a great ascetic. 'Ahaṅkāra' is the deep ego-identification that makes the person feel their severe practices set them above others. 'Kāma-rāga-bala' reveals the true drivers: underneath the appearance of renunciation lies intense desire, passion, and the violence of forceful will.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that the Gita here specifically targets austerities that are 'aśāstra-vihita' — not prescribed by scripture. The scriptures prescribe austerities in right measure, with right motive, and in a way that purifies without destroying. Going beyond these in the name of greater renunciation, when actually driven by ego and desire for spiritual status, is the very opposite of genuine tapas. The five qualities listed — dambha, ahaṅkāra, kāma, rāga, bala — are all forms of the same fundamental error: the ego asserting itself even through the vehicle of apparent self-denial.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda was emphatic that true spiritual austerity is defined by inner detachment and love for God, not by physical severity. He often taught that extreme self-mortification, unless divinely guided, produces pride rather than humility and agitation rather than peace. The five qualities described here — ostentation, ego, desire, passion, force — are exactly what excessive, ego-driven asceticism produces and feeds. Yogananda recommended the 'middle path' of balanced, scriptural austerity that gradually purifies without breaking the instrument of body and mind needed for God-realization.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka emphasizes that the fundamental problem with the practices described in this verse is their motivation. Tapas (austerity) in itself is valuable and necessary — the entire Gita recommends it. But when it is performed with 'dambhāhaṅkāra-saṃyuktāḥ' — combined with showmanship and ego — and 'kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ' — driven by underlying desire, passion, and forceful willfulness — it becomes inverted: the outward form of renunciation concealing inward attachment and pride. Such practices not only fail to purify but actively strengthen the very tendencies they appear to combat.

verses.sanskrit:
कर्शयन्तः शरीर-स्थं भूत-ग्रामम् अचेतसः ।
मां चैवान्तः शरीर-स्थं तान् विद्ध्य् आसुर-निश्चयान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
karśayantaḥ śarīra-sthaṃ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ |
māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-sthaṃ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān ||
verses.translation: ...senselessly (acetasaḥ) tormenting the elements/beings dwelling within the body, and also Me who am seated within the body — know them to be of demoniac resolve (āsura-niścayān).

word_breakdown.meaning: dwelling in the body (śarīra = body, stha = abiding)
the collection of elements / all the beings/constituents that compose the body
of demoniac resolve / with demonic determination (āsura = demonic, niścaya = resolve/certainty)

commentary.dadaji: The culminating phrase of this two-verse passage is electrifying: 'māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-stham' — and they also torment ME who dwell within the body. This is Krishna's most personal objection to extreme self-mortification. It is not simply that such practices are unhealthy or unsound — they actually injure the Lord's own dwelling place. The body is the temple of the Divine. To abuse it in the name of spirituality is a contradiction: one claims to seek God while attacking the very home in which God resides. 'Āsura-niścayān' — of demoniac resolve — is a severe verdict that connects back to Chapter 16's description of the āsurī nature.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'bhūta-grāmam' — the collection of elements or beings within the body — refers to the five elements and the prāṇas, the very constituents of life itself. Acetasaḥ — 'senselessly' or 'without consciousness' — is the key qualifier: such people torment the body without understanding what the body actually is: a temporary home of the ātman and a vehicle for mokṣa. The body is not the enemy; tamasic and rajasic conditioning of the mind is the enemy. 'Tān viddhy āsura-niścayān' — know them to be of demoniac resolve — is a direct cross-reference to Chapter 16, uniting the themes of that chapter with this one.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda was deeply moved by the phrase 'māṃ caivāntaḥ śarīra-stham' — 'Me also, who dwell within the body.' He taught that the body is the temple of God, housing not only the ātman but also the divine life-force (prāṇa) that is itself an expression of the Divine. Extreme self-mortification that destroys health and vitality is not spirituality but a form of violence against God's own creation and dwelling place. Genuine tapas purifies and strengthens the body-mind instrument; it does not shatter it. Yogananda's path of Kriya Yoga is precisely a balanced, scientific austerity that refines rather than destroys.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka observes that 'āsura-niścayān' — demoniac resolve — is a strong and precise term. The āsura does not lack determination or effort; the āsura lacks right knowledge and right motive. These extreme ascetics have resolve and effort in abundance — but it is resolve in service of ego and inverted desire, not genuine surrender to God. This makes them more dangerous than ordinary worldly people, because they use the outer forms of spirituality to camouflage deep-seated ego-assertion. The Gita's verdict is compassionate but clear: such practices, no matter how impressive outwardly, lead in the opposite direction from liberation.

verses.sanskrit:
आहारस् त्व् अपि सर्वस्य त्रि-विधो भवति प्रियः ।
यज्ञस् तपस् तथा दानं तेषां भेदम् इमं शृणु ॥
verses.transliteration:
āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ |
yajñas tapas tathā dānaṃ teṣāṃ bhedam imaṃ śṛṇu ||
verses.translation: And even the food (āhāra) that is dear to each person is of three kinds; likewise sacrifice (yajña), austerity (tapas), and charity (dāna) are also threefold. Hear about these distinctions (bhedam).

commentary.dadaji: This transitional verse is the pivot of the chapter. Having established that faith is threefold (v2-4), and having described misguided austerity (v5-6), Krishna now announces that He will analyze four more domains through the three-guṇa lens: food (āhāra), sacrifice (yajña), austerity (tapas), and charity (dāna). These four cover nearly the entire range of practical human life — what you eat, what you worship, how you discipline yourself, and how you give. The repetition of 'śṛṇu' (hear) signals again that what follows is teaching of special importance.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes the profound inclusiveness of this verse: even food preferences — something as apparently mundane as what one likes to eat — are not random or neutral, but express and reinforce one's guṇic constitution. The Gita treats nothing in human life as trivial; every choice, even dietary, is a spiritual datum. Yajña (sacrifice/worship), tapas (austerity), and dāna (charity) are the three pillars of traditional Indian religious life. Krishna will show that each can be performed in sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic modes — and the mode determines the fruit.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught extensively about the spiritual dimension of diet, rooted in precisely this Gita teaching. Food carries vibration — the prana in food affects the consciousness of the eater. This is why Yogananda emphasized a sattvic vegetarian diet as a foundation for meditation practice. But he also emphasized that all four categories here — food, worship, self-discipline, and giving — must be brought into the sattvic mode for holistic spiritual growth. A person can meditate daily (sattvic worship) but eat tamasically and find their practice undermined; all aspects of life are interconnected in the Gita's vision.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka points out that the four categories of this verse — āhāra, yajña, tapas, dāna — constitute the four pillars of practical dharmic life. Food sustains the body; sacrifice maintains the cosmic order and connection with the divine; austerity purifies the inner instrument; charity expresses and cultivates love for all beings. The fact that each of these can be sattvic, rajasic, or tamasic means that genuine spiritual life requires the purification of all four domains simultaneously. Attending to one while neglecting the others creates imbalance. The Gita here offers a comprehensive checklist for self-assessment.

verses.sanskrit:
आयुः-सत्त्व-बलारोग्य-सुख-प्रीति-विवर्धनाः ।
रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विक-प्रियाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
āyuḥ-sattva-balārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ |
rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvika-priyāḥ ||
verses.translation: Foods that increase lifespan (āyus), purity of mind (sattva), strength (bala), health (ārogya), happiness (sukha), and delight (prīti) — which are juicy (rasyāḥ), smooth/oleaginous (snigdhāḥ), substantial (sthirāḥ), and pleasant to the heart (hṛdyāḥ) — these are dear to the sattvic.

word_breakdown.meaning: pleasing to the heart / agreeable / wholesome
dear to the sattvic / preferred by those of sattvic nature

commentary.dadaji: Notice the richness of this verse: sattvic food promotes six qualities — āyus (long life), sattva (clarity), bala (strength), ārogya (health), sukha (wellbeing), and prīti (inner joy and love). It possesses four sensory qualities — rasyā (juicy, full of life-essence), snigdha (smooth and nourishing), sthira (firm and sustaining), hṛdya (naturally agreeable). This is food that is alive, fresh, naturally sweet, and genuinely nourishing — food that satisfies the body without agitating the mind. Sattvic diet is not about rigid rules but about choosing what supports life, clarity, and inner peace.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'rasa' in 'rasyāḥ' has a deeper meaning than 'juicy' — it refers to the essence or life-force present in fresh, vital food. 'Snigdha' — smooth and oleaginous — refers to properly prepared foods with good fats that nourish the tissues. 'Sthira' — firm and substantial — means food that provides lasting nourishment rather than quick stimulation followed by a crash. 'Hṛdya' — pleasing to the heart — suggests that sattvic food is naturally agreeable to a balanced constitution, not craved through artificial stimulation of the taste buds. This is the ancient Ayurvedic vision of food as medicine for body, mind, and soul.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda frequently cited this verse as the Gita's nutritional guidance. He taught that fresh fruits, vegetables, grains, legumes, dairy, and natural sweeteners are the sattvic foods par excellence. These six benefits — āyus, sattva, bala, ārogya, sukha, prīti — are exactly what a meditator needs: longevity to complete the spiritual journey, mental clarity for sustained meditation, physical strength for spiritual practice, health to avoid distraction by illness, happiness as the natural mood of a balanced mind, and prīti (love and delight) as the emotional tone of the devotee. Diet and consciousness are intimately linked.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka emphasizes that the six benefits of sattvic food span the full spectrum of human well-being: āyus (physical lifespan), sattva (mental quality), bala (physical energy), ārogya (absence of disease), sukha (experiential happiness), and prīti (the subtler joy of love and contentment). This is not a diet for physical health alone but a diet for integrated well-being at every level. The four qualities — rasyā, snigdha, sthira, hṛdya — describe food that is genuinely nourishing rather than merely stimulating. Such food promotes the inner quiet and clarity that make meditation and self-knowledge possible.

verses.sanskrit:
कट्व्-अम्ल-लवणात्य्-उष्ण-तीक्ष्ण-रूक्ष-विदाहिनः ।
आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःख-शोकामय-प्रदाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
kaṭv-amla-lavaṇāty-uṣṇa-tīkṣṇa-rūkṣa-vidāhinaḥ |
āhārā rājasasyeṣṭā duḥkha-śokāmaya-pradāḥ ||
verses.translation: Foods that are bitter (kaṭu), sour (amla), salty (lavaṇa), excessively hot (aty-uṣṇa), pungent (tīkṣṇa), dry (rūkṣa), and burning (vidāhī) — these are dear to the rajasic (rājasasyeṣṭāḥ); they produce pain (duḥkha), grief (śoka), and disease (āmaya).

commentary.dadaji: The seven qualities of rajasic food are all modes of excess and intensity: excessively bitter, sour, salty, hot, sharp, dry, and burning. These are not intrinsically forbidden tastes — bitter, sour, and salty are part of the Ayurvedic six tastes — but it is the excess and habitual preference for such stimulation that marks rajas. The rajasic person is always seeking more stimulation, sharper sensations, stronger experiences. This extends from food to entertainment, relationships, and ambition. The consequence — 'duḥkha-śoka-āmaya-pradāḥ' — is striking: physical pain, emotional grief, and physical disease, all arising from the over-stimulated, inflamed constitution.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that Ayurveda and the Gita agree on this analysis: excessively stimulating food creates āma (toxic residue), aggravates pitta (the fire principle), and disturbs vāta (the air principle), leading to both physical disease and mental agitation. The emotional consequences — duḥkha (physical pain) and śoka (mental grief) — reveal the mind-body connection: an agitated digestive system agitates the nervous system and mind, creating anxiety, irritability, and emotional volatility. The rajasic person eats for the stimulation of taste rather than for genuine nourishment, just as they act for the stimulation of results rather than for genuine service.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that overly spiced, fried, heavily salted, and processed foods fall into the rajasic category. Such foods excite the senses and the passional nature, making calm meditation difficult. He observed that people who habitually eat very spicy or stimulating food find their minds more prone to agitation, anger, and restlessness. This is not a rigid prohibition but a recognition of cause and effect: rajasic food feeds rajasic consciousness. For those on the spiritual path seeking inner stillness, gradually moving toward sattvic food — while not becoming fanatical about it — supports the meditative life.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka clarifies that the problem with rajasic foods is not the tastes themselves (bitter, sour, salty, hot are all natural and present in sattvic foods in balanced measure) but the excess and the habitual craving for stimulation. 'Aty-uṣṇa' — excessively hot — is the key qualifier. Rajas is always about excess and intensity. The three results — duḥkha (pain), śoka (sorrow), āmaya (disease) — correspond to three levels: physical, emotional, and pathological. Rajasic diet ultimately produces suffering at all three levels, even if it provides temporary pleasure and stimulation. This teaching supports the practice of mitāhāra — moderation in food.

verses.sanskrit:
यात-यामं गत-रसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत् ।
उच्छिष्टम् अपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामस-प्रियम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
yāta-yāmaṃ gata-rasaṃ pūti paryuṣitaṃ ca yat |
ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṃ bhojanaṃ tāmasa-priyam ||
verses.translation: Food that is stale (yāta-yāmam), tasteless/devoid of essence (gata-rasam), putrid/rotten (pūtī), day-old/leftover (paryuṣitam), impure remnants (ucchiṣṭam), and ritually impure (amedhyam) — such food is dear to the tamasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: stale / time-passed (yāta = passed, yāma = a period of three hours; food past its prime)
devoid of taste/essence (gata = gone, rasa = essence/taste/life-force)
day-old / leftover / stale from previous day
remnants / leftovers / food touched and left by another
impure / ritually unclean / unfit for sacred use
dear to the tamasic / preferred by those of tamasic nature

commentary.dadaji: Tamasic food is food from which life has departed. 'Yāta-yāmam' — time-passed — refers not just to old food but to the concept that food has a life-span: fresh food is vibrant with prāṇa, and as time passes, that prāṇa dissipates. 'Gata-rasam' — from which rasa has gone — is the perfect image: rasa is both taste and the subtle life-essence that nourishes consciousness. Stale, rotten, leftover food may fill the stomach but does not nourish the soul. The person who habitually prefers such food — and is content with it — reveals a consciousness that has become indifferent to quality, vitality, and purity.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda notes that 'amedhyam' — ritually impure — carries a broader meaning than mere ceremonial uncleanliness. It refers to food that is unfit to offer to the divine, and since one's own body is the temple of the divine, what one eats is in a sense an offering to the Lord within. Tamasic food insults this inner temple. 'Ucchiṣṭam' — remnants left by others — is specifically food that carries another's energetic imprint after being partially consumed, considered spiritually depleting. The overall picture is of a person who has given up on quality entirely — who feeds the body without any attention to what nourishes the mind and soul.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that food is not merely biochemical fuel but a carrier of prāṇa — subtle life-energy. This is why he emphasized fresh, freshly cooked, wholesome food. Tamasic food — stale, rotten, processed, devitalized — contains little or no prāṇa and actually weighs down the consciousness with inertia, dullness, and sleep. The person who habitually eats such food finds their mind heavy, their thoughts sluggish, and their spiritual aspiration dampened. 'Gata-rasam' — from which the rasa has gone — perfectly describes modern processed food: it may taste artificially flavored but is devoid of the subtle life-essence that genuine food carries.
commentary.goyandka: Śrī Goyandka observes that this verse's description of tamasic food goes beyond physical spoilage to address the energetic and spiritual dimension of food. 'Yāta-yāmam' establishes the principle that food has a temporal quality — its prāṇa diminishes with time. 'Gata-rasam' establishes that what we seek in food is not just calories but rasa — the quintessence of nourishment. Tamasic food has lost both. The result of habitually eating such food is the reinforcement of tamas in the mind — heaviness, sloth, dullness, indifference, and an inability to aspire toward the higher. Just as sattvic food feeds the light in consciousness, tamasic food feeds the darkness.

verses.sanskrit: अफल-काङ्क्षिभिर् यज्ञो विधि-दिष्टो य इज्यते । यष्टव्यम् एवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः ॥
verses.transliteration: aphala-kāṅkṣibhir yajño vidhi-diṣṭo ya ijyate | yaṣṭavyam eveti manaḥ samādhāya sa sāttvikaḥ ||
verses.translation: That sacrifice which is offered according to prescribed method, by those who do not seek fruit, with the mind focused on the conviction 'this is to be offered as a duty' — that is sattvic.

word_breakdown.meaning: by those who do not desire fruit
prescribed by scriptural injunction / according to method
this alone is to be offered / it is my duty to sacrifice
sattvic / of the nature of sattva

commentary.dadaji: The sattvic sacrifice is one of pure offering — the mind is settled in the conviction 'yaṣṭavyam eva,' this is simply what must be done. There is no agenda, no hidden expectation. Vidhi-diṣṭa means the act is grounded in dharma and scripture, not personal whim. Aphala-kāṅkṣī means the fruit is surrendered before the action even begins. This is the highest form of worship: duty performed as an act of love toward the divine, without any return address.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Krishna gives us three precise tests for sattvic yajna in this verse. First: is it done according to right method and scripture? Second: is the doer free from desire for any result? Third: is the mind anchored in the pure intention 'I must do this as my duty'? When all three converge, the sacrifice becomes sattvic — luminous, clear, and purifying for the one who performs it. Most of our religious acts fail one or more of these tests, and that is worth examining honestly.
commentary.yogananda: The sattvic devotee performs every sacred act as an offering to God, with no thought of personal benefit. 'Samādhāya manaḥ' — the mind is gathered and placed in the fire of offering itself. This is the yoga of action meeting the yoga of devotion: every rite becomes a meditation, every flame a prayer. When a devotee truly releases the fruit, the act becomes transparent — God acts through them, and the offering returns purified as divine grace.
commentary.goyandka: The hallmark of sattvic sacrifice is threefold: performance according to prescribed injunction (vidhi-diṣṭa), complete desirelessness regarding fruit (aphala-kāṅkṣitā), and mental resolve in the sense of duty (yaṣṭavyam iti manaḥ samādhāna). These three together indicate an act performed in full purity of motive. Śāstra-prescribed rites performed without desire are the foundation of spiritual progress; they purify the antaḥkaraṇa and create the conditions for knowledge to arise.

verses.sanskrit: अभिसन्धाय तु फलं दम्भार्थम् अपि चैव यत् । इज्यते भरत-श्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम् ॥
verses.transliteration: abhisandhāya tu phalaṃ dambhārtham api caiva yat | ijyate bharata-śreṣṭha taṃ yajñaṃ viddhi rājasam ||
verses.translation: But that sacrifice which is performed with the aim of gaining fruit, and also for ostentation, O Best of Bharatas — know that sacrifice to be rajasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: having aimed at / fixing the mind on
for the purpose of show / for ostentation
rajasic / of the nature of rajas

commentary.dadaji: Two motives corrupt the sacrifice and make it rajasic: abhisandhāya phalam — the mind clinging to the result, and dambha — the desire to be seen, praised, respected. Religion performed for social standing is not worship; it is self-promotion in sacred garb. The 'tu' at the start marks a contrast with the sattvic verse: where the sattvic person surrenders the fruit, the rajasic person grasps it; where the sattvic person is inward, the rajasic person is performing for an audience.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Abhisandhāya means the mind has already calculated the return — it fixes on the fruit before the act is even complete. Dambhārtham means the performance is designed to impress others. These two motives — desire and display — are the twin engines of rajasic religiosity. Notice how common this is: we perform rites to get something (health, wealth, success) or to be seen as pious. Krishna sees through both with his characteristic precision.
commentary.yogananda: The rajasic worshipper uses the sacred as a means to personal ends — this is the subtle corruption of spiritual practice. Dambha, hypocrisy or display, is particularly insidious because it wears the costume of devotion while pursuing pride. The great ones have always taught: do not let the left hand know what the right hand gives. When worship becomes a performance for others, the divine presence withdraws, and only the audience remains.
commentary.goyandka: Rajasic sacrifice is characterized by two defects that invert the purpose of yajña. First, phala-abhisandhi — the mental attachment to results, which binds rather than liberates. Second, dambha — performing for recognition, which feeds the ego rather than dissolving it. Such sacrifice generates karma and keeps the jīva bound to the cycle of cause and effect. It may generate some worldly merit, but it does not lead to the purification of the antaḥkaraṇa that genuine yajña is meant to accomplish.

verses.sanskrit: विधि-हीनम् असृष्टान्नं मन्त्र-हीनम् अदक्षिणम् । श्रद्धा-विरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते ॥
verses.transliteration: vidhi-hīnam asṛṣṭānnaṃ mantra-hīnam adakṣiṇam | śraddhā-virahitaṃ yajñaṃ tāmasaṃ paricakṣate ||
verses.translation: A sacrifice contrary to prescribed method, in which no food is distributed, in which there are no sacred chants, no sacrificial gifts, and which is devoid of faith — such a sacrifice they call tamasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: devoid of prescribed method / contrary to injunction
in which food is not distributed (a + sṛṣṭa + anna)
without sacrificial gifts / dakṣiṇā to officiants
tamasic / of the nature of tamas

commentary.dadaji: The tamasic sacrifice is emptied of every sacred element: no method, no food shared with others, no mantra, no dakṣiṇā to the priests, and — most devastatingly — no śraddhā. Without faith, no rite has any soul. Śraddhā-virahita is the deepest deficiency: you can restore method and mantra, but a faithless heart cannot be repaired by external form alone. This describes either superstitious ritual performed mechanically or dark practices done in secrecy without any of the hallmarks of genuine worship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Notice the completeness of this verse — five separate deficiencies are listed, and any one of them is enough to vitiate the sacredness of the act. Tamasic sacrifice is not merely impure; it is a hollow shell. No food distributed means no generosity (yajña is inherently communal). No mantra means no invocation of the sacred. No dakṣiṇā means no honor to those who serve. And no śraddhā means the inner fire is out. Empty ritual performed out of habit, fear, or superstition falls squarely here.
commentary.yogananda: Tamas is the quality of inertia, darkness, and unconsciousness — and when it enters worship, the sacred act becomes its opposite. The five absences described here represent the complete absence of light, love, and life from a religious performance. Śraddhā — faith — is the animating principle without which all other elements are dead forms. The spiritual seeker must regularly examine their own practice: is it alive? Is it conscious? Does it open the heart, or merely occupy the body?
commentary.goyandka: Tamasic yajña fails on every dimension recognized by the śāstras. Vidhi-hīna means it transgresses or ignores the prescribed order. Asṛṣṭānna means the prasāda that should be shared with all is withheld. Mantra-hīna means the divine is not properly invoked. Adakṣiṇa means the relationship between yajamāna and ṛtvij is broken. And śraddhā-virahita means the entire act is performed without the inner illumination of faith. Such a sacrifice generates no spiritual merit and may even generate negative karma through the violation of sacred norms.

verses.sanskrit: देव-द्विज-गुरु-प्राज्ञ-पूजनं शौचम् आर्जवम् । ब्रह्म-चर्यम् अहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjanaṃ śaucam ārjavam | brahma-caryam ahiṃsā ca śārīraṃ tapa ucyate ||
verses.translation: Worship of the gods, the twice-born, teachers, and the wise — purity, uprightness, celibacy, and non-violence — this is called the austerity of the body.

word_breakdown.meaning: the twice-born / brahmins (those born once physically, once spiritually through initiation)
the wise / those of deep wisdom
celibacy / restraint of vital energies / walking in Brahman
is called / is said to be

commentary.dadaji: Bodily austerity, śārīra tapa, is not about physical punishment — it is about how the body moves through the world. Five disciplines: honoring those worthy of honor (which orients the body in humility), śauca (maintaining purity of body and environment), ārjava (the body's actions matching the inner intention), brahmacarya (directing vital energy toward the divine), and ahiṃsā (the body's fundamental non-aggression). These are the grammar of a sacred life expressed through action.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: It is remarkable that Krishna begins bodily austerity not with fasting or posture but with pūjana — worship, reverence, the bowing of the body before what is worthy. This sets the tone: śārīra tapa is not self-punishment but self-orientation toward the sacred. Brahmacarya here is not mere celibacy but the broader channeling of all energy — including sexual, emotional, and creative — toward spiritual life. Ahiṃsā as a bodily discipline means making the body itself an instrument of peace.
commentary.yogananda: The body is the temple of the soul, and these five disciplines are how one keeps that temple consecrated. Brahmacarya is the conservation of the life-force (prāṇa-śakti), which when transmuted upward becomes the fuel for deep meditation and spiritual awakening. Ahiṃsā is not passive but radiantly active — a body grounded in non-violence generates a field of peace around it that affects all who come near. These five together represent the body living as an act of continuous worship.
commentary.goyandka: Śārīra tapa as described here is entirely positive — it is the body engaged in uplifting activities, not the body being tortured. The first element, deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjana, is itself an austerity: the ego bows before wisdom, before learning, before the divine — and in that bowing, it is refined. Śauca, ārjava, brahmacarya, and ahiṃsā complete the picture of a body lived in alignment with dharma. This is distinct from the tamasic austerity of self-torture described in verse 19, which is explicitly condemned.

verses.sanskrit: अनुद्वेग-करं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रिय-हितं च यत् । स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्-मयं तप उच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: anudvega-karaṃ vākyaṃ satyaṃ priya-hitaṃ ca yat | svādhyāyābhyasanaṃ caiva vāṅ-mayaṃ tapa ucyate ||
verses.translation: Speech that does not cause agitation, that is truthful, pleasant, and beneficial, along with regular practice of Vedic recitation — this is called the austerity of speech.

word_breakdown.meaning: not causing agitation or distress (an + udvega + kara)
regular practice of Vedic study and recitation (svādhyāya + abhyasana)
consisting of speech / pertaining to speech (vāc + maya)
is called / is said to be

commentary.dadaji: This is the four-filter teaching for speech — before any word leaves the mouth, ask: will it cause agitation? Is it true? Is it kind? Is it beneficial? All four must be answered well. And the fifth element, svādhyāya, means the mouth is not only restrained from harm but positively engaged in scripture. The discipline of speech is not silence alone but the cultivation of speech that heals, illumines, and uplifts. Every word is either a blessing or a burden to the world.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Notice the sophistication of this verse. Satya alone is not enough — a truth spoken harshly that serves no purpose is not vāṅ-maya tapa. Priya alone is not enough — flattery that harms is not austerity. Hita alone is not enough — a beneficial statement can still be delivered in a way that causes pain. All four must converge: not agitating, true, pleasing, and beneficial. And beneath all speech practice, svādhyāya — the recitation of scripture — sanctifies the very instrument of the voice.
commentary.yogananda: The voice is a sacred instrument. It can carry the vibration of mantra, scripture, and divine name, or it can carry the vibration of anger, falsehood, and cruelty. Vāṅ-maya tapa is the discipline of filling that instrument with only what is worthy. Svādhyāya — regular recitation of the Vedas, Gītā, or any scripture — purifies the subtle channels through which speech flows, making the voice itself a medium of grace. The great ṛṣis knew that speech is not merely communication; it is creation.
commentary.goyandka: Vāṅ-maya tapa has two aspects: the negative (avoiding harmful speech) and the positive (engaging speech in sacred recitation). The four qualities of right speech — anudvega-kara, satya, priya, hita — represent a progressive refinement: the speech must not harm, must be true, must be pleasant, and must be good for the listener. These are hierarchically ordered — non-harm is the minimum floor. Svādhyāyābhyasana elevates the austerity further: the tongue that recites scripture daily becomes an instrument of dharma rather than merely an instrument of communication.

verses.sanskrit: मनः-प्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनं आत्म-विनिग्रहः । भाव-संशुद्धिर् इत्य् एतत् तपो मानसम् उच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: manaḥ-prasādaḥ saumyatvaṃ maunaṃ ātma-vinigrahaḥ | bhāva-saṃśuddhir ity etat tapo mānasam ucyate ||
verses.translation: Serenity of mind, gentleness, silence, self-control, and purity of being — this is called mental austerity.

word_breakdown.meaning: serenity / clarity / cheerfulness of mind (manas + prasāda)
self-control / mastery over the self (ātman + vinigraha)
purity of being / purity of intention (bhāva + saṃśuddhi)
is called / is said to be

commentary.dadaji: The deepest austerity is the most invisible: the disciplining of the mind itself. Manaḥ-prasāda is not a forced cheerfulness but the natural clarity that comes when the mind is not churned by desire and fear. Saumyatva is the warmth and gentleness that radiates from a composed mind. Mauna is the silence beneath all thought. Ātma-vinigraha is self-mastery — not suppression but governance. And bhāva-saṃśuddhi is the ultimate purification: when even the root motivation is clean, every act that flows from it is sacred.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse completes the triad of bodily, verbal, and mental austerity. The mental is the most subtle and the most primary — because the body and speech both take their direction from the mind. Bhāva-saṃśuddhi — purity of bhāva — is the key: bhāva means the deep emotional-intentional state, the 'why' beneath all action. When the bhāva is pure, even imperfect external acts carry spiritual weight. When the bhāva is impure, even technically perfect external acts carry no sacred value.
commentary.yogananda: Mauna — true silence — is not the mere absence of words but the settling of the mind into its own nature. The great masters have said that the deepest meditation begins where words end. Manaḥ-prasāda, the grace-state of the mind, is the same word used for the prasāda distributed after worship: the mind itself becomes prasāda — sanctified, offered, and returned. Bhāva-saṃśuddhi is the fruit of all spiritual practice: when the heart is clean, the divine sees itself reflected there.
commentary.goyandka: Mānasa tapa is the subtlest and most demanding of the three austerities because the mind is the hardest faculty to govern. Manaḥ-prasāda requires that the mind remain calm regardless of external circumstances — this is the mark of a truly disciplined practitioner. Ātma-vinigraha means the self has genuine sovereignty over its own processes — not repression, which breeds rajas, but genuine mastery, which is sattvic. Bhāva-saṃśuddhi — purity of intention — ensures that all outward practice is rooted in genuine aspiration rather than social performance.

verses.sanskrit: श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस् तत् त्रि-विधं नरैः । अफल-काङ्क्षिभिर् युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते ॥
verses.transliteration: śraddhayā parayā taptaṃ tapas tat tri-vidhaṃ naraiḥ | aphala-kāṅkṣibhir yuktaiḥ sāttvikaṃ paricakṣate ||
verses.translation: This threefold austerity practiced with supreme faith, by persons who do not seek fruit and who are engaged and integrated — that they call sattvic.

word_breakdown.meaning: practiced / performed / undergone (past passive participle of tap)
threefold / of three kinds (body + speech + mind)
by those who are integrated / engaged / yoked (to the divine)
sattvic / of the nature of sattva
they call / they declare / it is regarded as

commentary.dadaji: This summary verse ties together all three levels of austerity — body, speech, and mind — and names the conditions that make them sattvic: supreme faith (śraddhayā parayā), no desire for fruit (aphala-kāṅkṣā), and genuine engagement (yukta). The word 'parayā' — 'supreme' or 'highest' — is significant: ordinary faith is not enough; the faith must be total, whole-hearted, without reservation. When all three levels of being are offered together in such faith, the result is a life that is itself an act of worship.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Four conditions converge to make austerity sattvic: it is tri-vidha (encompassing body, speech, and mind — not just physical), it is practiced with supreme faith (not mechanical habit), it is desireless (aphala-kāṅkṣī), and the practitioner is yukta — integrated, spiritually engaged. Any of these missing shifts the tapa toward rajas or tamas. This verse is the synthesis: genuine spiritual discipline is total, faithful, desireless, and whole-hearted.
commentary.yogananda: Śraddhayā parayā — with the highest faith — means the austerity is performed not from fear of punishment or hope of reward, but from the devotee's direct love of God. When faith reaches this supreme level, austerity is no longer difficult; it becomes natural, even joyful. Yuktaiḥ — those who are 'yoked' — are those whose individual will has become aligned with the divine will. In this state, even austerity becomes a form of samādhi: every discipline a doorway into the presence.
commentary.goyandka: This verse establishes the fourfold criterion for sattvic tapa: the austerity must span all three levels (tri-vidha), must be grounded in the highest faith (śraddhā parā), must be free from desire for results (aphala-kāṅkṣā), and must be performed by one who is spiritually engaged (yukta). Tri-vidha is particularly important: an austerity that disciplines the body but neglects the mind, or trains speech but allows the bhāva to remain impure, is incomplete. True sattvic tapa is an integrated, whole-being offering.

verses.sanskrit: सत्कार-मान-पूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत् । क्रियते तद् इह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलम् अध्रुवम् ॥
verses.transliteration: satkāra-māna-pūjārthaṃ tapo dambhena caiva yat | kriyate tad iha proktaṃ rājasaṃ calam adhruvam ||
verses.translation: Austerity that is practiced with ostentation, for the sake of honor, respect, and worship from others — that is declared here to be rajasic: impermanent and unstable.

word_breakdown.meaning: for the sake of worship / adoration

commentary.dadaji: Satkāra-māna-pūjā: respectful treatment, honor, worship from others. These are the real fruits that the rajasic practitioner is after — not mokṣa or purification, but a certain social standing, a reputation for piety. 'Calam adhruvam' — impermanent and unstable — is the precise diagnosis: because the foundation is external (others' opinions), when others' opinions change, the fruit dissolves. The tapasvin who practises for reputation will find their reward is as fleeting as reputation itself.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse is a mirror held up to much of what passes for spiritual practice in public life. Dambhena — with display, with hypocrisy — is the operative word. The outer form of the practice may be perfectly correct; the austerity may be genuinely difficult. But if the motive is satkāra (to be received with honor), māna (to be respected), and pūjā (to be worshipped), then the act is rajasic. 'Calam adhruvam' is not a punishment but a natural consequence: social fruits are inherently unstable.
commentary.yogananda: Spiritual vanity is the subtlest of all vanities — the ego using the very instruments of self-transcendence to reassert itself. The spiritual celebrity who fasts publicly, who broadcasts renunciation, who performs austerity for followers — this is what Krishna diagnoses here with characteristic precision. Calam adhruvam: the fruits earned through display are as unstable as a flame in the wind. Genuine tapa performed in secret, without an audience, accumulates a power that no social recognition can match.
commentary.goyandka: Rajasic tapa generates merit but of a limited and unstable kind. 'Calam' means the result moves — it is not fixed in the practitioner's being but dependent on external conditions. 'Adhruvam' means it does not endure — when the rajas burns out, the fruit falls away. The antaḥkaraṇa of a rajasic practitioner is not purified by such practice; rather, the ego is strengthened and the attachment to social recognition grows. This is why rajas in spiritual practice is actually more dangerous than tamas — it masquerades as virtue.

verses.sanskrit: मूढ-ग्राहेणात्मनो यत् पीडया क्रियते तपः । परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत् तामसम् उदाहृतम् ॥
verses.transliteration: mūḍha-grāheṇātmano yat pīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ | parasyotsādanārtham vā tat tāmasam udāhṛtam ||
verses.translation: Austerity that is performed with deluded conviction, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another — that is declared to be tamasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: with pain / by tormenting / through self-torture
for the purpose of destroying / ruining (utsādana + artha)
tamasic / of the nature of tamas

commentary.dadaji: Three marks of tamasic austerity: mūḍha-grāha (stubborn delusion — convinced one is right while being profoundly wrong), ātmanaḥ pīḍā (self-torture, confusing pain with purification), and parasyotsādana (using spiritual power to harm others — the dark inverse of genuine tapas). Krishna here explicitly condemns extreme self-mortification — the Gītā's path is not one of physical torture but of awakened, conscious discipline. And 'utsādanārtham' reveals something profound: tamas can weaponize spiritual practice.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Mūḍha-grāha is the key phrase: 'grāha' means to grasp, to seize, and 'mūḍha' means deluded. The tamasic practitioner seizes onto their practice with the grip of delusion — convinced that what they are doing is correct, spiritual, even heroic, while it is actually harmful to themselves and others. This is the tragic dimension of tamasic spirituality: it cannot see itself. The self-torturer and the occultist who uses siddhis to harm others both believe they are doing something meaningful — and both are in the grip of tamas.
commentary.yogananda: This verse draws a clear line between genuine tapas and self-destructive mortification. The Gītā consistently rejects extreme asceticism — the body is the vehicle for liberation, not the enemy to be destroyed. Mūḍha-grāha is the spirit of fanaticism that mistakes suffering for sanctity. And 'parasyotsādanārtham' — austerity aimed at destroying another — represents the perversion of spiritual power into black magic or destructive intention. Both arise from the same root: the absence of light (tamas) and the confusion of destruction with purification.
commentary.goyandka: Tamasic austerity is dangerous precisely because it can appear severe and impressive from the outside. Extreme self-mortification is often admired by onlookers while being profoundly harmful to the practitioner. Krishna's verdict is unambiguous: ātmanaḥ pīḍā — self-torture — is not tapas but its tamasic counterfeit. And parasyotsādana — using any practice, including concentrated willpower and ritual, to destroy an enemy — is among the darkest expressions of tamas. True tapa always moves toward life, light, and liberation.

verses.sanskrit: दातव्यम् इति यद् दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे । देशे काले च पात्रे च तद् दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम् ॥
verses.transliteration: dātavyam iti yad dānaṃ dīyate'nupakāriṇe | deśe kāle ca pātre ca tad dānaṃ sāttvikaṃ smṛtam ||
verses.translation: That gift which is given with the feeling 'it is to be given,' to one who cannot return the favor, at the right place, at the right time, and to a worthy recipient — that gift is known as sattvic.

word_breakdown.meaning: with the conviction 'it is to be given / it is my duty to give'
to one who does not / cannot return the favor (an + upakārin)
at the right place / in an appropriate location
at the right time / at an auspicious moment
to a worthy recipient / to a fit vessel (literally 'a vessel')
is remembered as / is regarded as / is known to be

commentary.dadaji: Dāna is the natural overflow of a sattvic heart, and this verse defines when that overflow is pure. 'Dātavyam iti' — the sense of duty to give, not because of who will receive but because giving is right. 'Anupakāriṇe' is particularly luminous: give to the one who cannot repay you, because that gift is completely free of any economic logic, any reciprocal calculation. Deśa-kāla-pātra — the right conditions ensure the giving is wise, not merely sentimental. Sattvic dāna is both selfless and intelligent.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The phrase 'anupakāriṇe' — to one who cannot return the favor — is perhaps the most precise test of genuine generosity ever articulated. If I give expecting nothing back, even unconsciously, I fail this test. Sattvic dāna is given with the explicit sense that no return is possible or expected. Combined with deśa-kāla-pātra — wisdom about place, time, and worthy recipient — this is not naive charity but conscious, selfless giving that benefits both giver and receiver without creating dependency or waste.
commentary.yogananda: 'Dātavyam iti' — this is to be given — is the spirit of the divine itself expressing through the human. God gives without calculation: the sun does not ask whether the field deserves its light. When a devotee gives with this spirit, they participate in the divine abundance that underlies all creation. Pātra — the worthy vessel — is important: true giving is not indiscriminate but discerning, ensuring the gift serves the recipient's genuine spiritual and material growth rather than enabling harm.
commentary.goyandka: This verse opens the three-verse sequence on sattvic, rajasic, and tamasic dāna, paralleling the earlier treatments of yajña and tapa. The fourfold condition for sattvic dāna — dātavyam iti (duty-consciousness), anupakāriṇe (no expectation of return), deśa-kāla (right circumstance), pātra (worthy recipient) — represents the complete framework for dharmic generosity. Smṛtam — 'remembered as' or 'regarded as' — suggests this is not a new teaching but one preserved in the tradition: the ancient understanding of how giving becomes liberation rather than merely transaction.

verses.sanskrit: यत् तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलम् उद्दिश्य वा पुनः । दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद् दानं राजसं स्मृतम् ॥
verses.transliteration: yat tu pratyupakārārthaṃ phalam uddiśya vā punaḥ | dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṃ tad dānaṃ rājasaṃ smṛtam ||
verses.translation: But that gift which is given with the expectation of return (pratyupakārārtham), or with a specific result in mind (phalam uddiśya), or given grudgingly and with difficulty (parikliṣṭam) — that gift is remembered as rajasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: for the purpose of receiving something in return; expecting reciprocation
aiming at, targeting, with the intent of
grudgingly, with pain or reluctance, given under strain
rajasic; of the nature of rajas (passion, desire, restlessness)
is remembered, is declared, is known

commentary.dadaji: The rajasic giver is essentially a merchant of virtue — he gives only when he calculates a return. Three marks betray this attitude: he gives expecting reciprocation (pratyupakārārtham), he gives while mentally fixing on a specific reward (phalam uddiśya), and he gives with a sense of pain and reluctance (parikliṣṭam) as though parting with something precious. Such giving does not free the heart; it actually tightens the knot of ego and desire. True generosity is an outpouring — rajasic giving is a transaction. Notice that even if the outer act looks identical, the inner motive transforms the quality and fruit entirely.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda would observe that this verse exposes the contractual nature of rajasic charity. When we give and quietly calculate — 'now they owe me something' — we have turned generosity into a commercial exchange. The word parikliṣṭam is psychologically precise: there is actual inner pain or strain in the giving, because the rajasic person feels the loss of what he parts with. The ego is invested in holding and accumulating; every act of giving feels like a small wound. Such charity binds rather than liberates, because the giver's consciousness remains locked in the cycle of give-and-receive.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda would point to the spiritual law underlying this verse: giving with expectation of return keeps the soul orbiting in the wheel of karma, because every transaction creates a counter-transaction. The rajasic giver is trapped in the very cycle he hopes to benefit from. Parikliṣṭam — that inner grudgingness — is the telltale sign that the ego has not surrendered. Yogananda taught that true giving should feel like joy, a natural overflow of divine love. The moment giving becomes painful, calculated, or transactional, we know rajas is at work, and the spiritual benefit is lost even if the material deed is done.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka explains that the Gita here identifies the mercantile spirit (vyāpārika-buddhi) that can infect even acts of charity. Pratyupakārārtham means the giver secretly intends to recover his investment — whether in social goodwill, prestige, divine reward, or tangible return. Phalam uddiśya indicates the charity is aimed like an arrow at a specific result; it is not free giving at all, but a disguised desire. Parikliṣṭam reveals that giving actually goes against the person's nature at that moment — he feels the weight of the loss. Such charity accumulates rajasic karmic merit (puṇya) but cannot purify the heart or lead toward liberation.

verses.sanskrit: अदेश-काले यद् दानम् अपात्रेभ्यश् च दीयते । असत्कृतम् अवज्ञातं तत् तामसम् उदाहृतम् ॥
verses.transliteration: adeśa-kāle yad dānam apātrebhyaś ca dīyate | asatkṛtam avajñātaṃ tat tāmasam udāhṛtam ||
verses.translation: That gift which is given at the wrong place and wrong time (adeśa-kāle), to unworthy recipients (apātrebhyaḥ), without proper respect or honor (asatkṛtam), and with contempt (avajñātam) — that is declared tamasic.

word_breakdown.meaning: at the wrong place (adeśa) and wrong time (akāle); in an unfit location and inauspicious moment
whatever gift, whichever act of giving
to unworthy or unfit recipients (apātra — without the 'vessel', incapable of receiving worthily)
without proper respect or honor; carelessly, perfunctorily
with contempt, disdain, or disrespect toward the recipient
tamasic; of the nature of tamas (inertia, darkness, delusion)
is declared, is cited, is proclaimed

commentary.dadaji: Tamasic charity carries four defects that together make the giving harmful rather than beneficial. Adeśa-kāla means giving at a place or time that is spiritually or practically inauspicious — for instance, enabling destructive behavior. Apātra means giving to one who is incapable of using the gift well, or who will use it against dharma. Asatkṛta is the absence of honor — the gift is dumped rather than offered. Avajñāta adds active contempt: the giver looks down on the recipient while giving. When all four are present, what looks like generosity is actually a form of harm — it degrades the recipient, corrupts the act, and accumulates tamasic karma for the giver.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda would highlight that tamasic giving often masquerades as charity but produces no sattvic elevation in either party. The concept of apātra — the 'unfit vessel' — is not about social hierarchy but about capacity and intention. Giving knowledge to one who will misuse it, or giving money to enable addiction, qualifies as apātra-dāna. Asatkṛta (without honoring the recipient) and avajñāta (with contempt) reveal that the giver does not see the divine in the receiver — which is the very essence that makes giving sacred. Tamasic giving is charity stripped of its soul.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda would draw our attention to avajñātam — the attitude of contempt — as the spiritual poison that makes tamasic giving worse than no giving at all. When we give while looking down on the recipient, we reinforce the sense of separation and superiority that spiritual life aims to dissolve. The sattvic ideal is seeing every recipient as Nārāyaṇa, the Divine. Tamasic charity does the opposite — it uses the act of giving to assert the ego's superiority. Adeśa-kāla also teaches us that context matters: the same gift given at the wrong time or place can cause harm rather than good, and wisdom (viveka) must guide generosity.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka explains this verse as defining charity that is spiritually inert or actively destructive. The Shastras prescribe careful attention to pātra (worthy recipients), deśa (appropriate place — such as a pilgrimage site or temple), and kāla (auspicious time — such as eclipses, holy festivals). Tamasic giving ignores all these considerations. Worse still, it combines carelessness (asatkṛta) with disrespect (avajñāta). Such giving does not create puṇya for the giver — it creates pāpa, sin. The commentary tradition warns: ill-considered charity that places destructive means in harmful hands is among the gravest misapplications of what could otherwise be a purifying virtue.

verses.sanskrit: ॐ तत् सद् इति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस् त्रि-विधः स्मृतः । ब्राह्मणास् तेन वेदाश् च यज्ञाश् च विहिताः पुरा ॥
verses.transliteration: oṃ tat sad iti nirdeśo brahmaṇas tri-vidhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇās tena vedāś ca yajñāś ca vihitāḥ purā ||
verses.translation: "Om Tat Sat" — this threefold designation of Brahman is remembered. By this (tena), the brahmins, the Vedas, and the sacrifices were appointed and created of old (purā).

word_breakdown.meaning: the primordial sacred syllable; the vibrational name of Brahman; the affirmation of divine existence
'That' — the transcendent, indescribable Absolute; pointing beyond all name and form
'Being', 'Truth', 'the Real' — that which truly exists; the ultimate ground of reality
thus, in this manner; used to mark a quoted expression
of Brahman — the ultimate Reality, the Absolute
is remembered, is declared by tradition
the brahmins, the knowers and teachers of sacred knowledge
by that, from that — referring to Om Tat Sat
and the Vedas — the scriptures of divine revelation
of old, in ancient times, at the beginning of creation

commentary.dadaji: This verse is the axis around which the closing teaching of Chapter 17 turns. 'Om Tat Sat' is not merely a formula — it is the three-petaled flower of Brahman's self-revelation in sacred sound. Om affirms that Brahman IS — it is the syllable of pure existence and assent, the cosmic 'yes'. Tat points beyond everything that can be named or thought: 'That' — the nameless, formless Absolute that underlies all particular realities. Sat is being, truth, the real — what persists through all change. Together, Om Tat Sat expresses the full nature of Brahman: it exists (Om), it transcends (Tat), it is the very substance of truth (Sat). That from which all creation, all scripture, all sacrifice, all sacred culture flows — that is what this mantric triad names. When we use these syllables, we are not creating meaning; we are touching meaning that was always already there.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda would observe that 'Om Tat Sat' functions as a threefold pointer to the Absolute, each word approaching from a different angle. Om is the symbol of Brahman as the ground of all sound and being — Mandukya Upanishad devotes itself entirely to unpacking Om. Tat — 'That' — appears famously in the mahāvākya 'Tat tvam asi' (That thou art): it is the pronoun of the Infinite, used precisely because no noun could contain it. Sat is the ontological claim: Brahman is the only thing that truly is (sat), while everything else is contingent and perishable. The tradition preserved these three syllables as the most condensed and complete designations of Ultimate Reality. The verse then grounds all of Vedic civilization — brahmins, Vedas, yajñas — in this sacred triad, showing that sacred culture is not a human invention but an expression of the Absolute itself.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda would dwell on Om as the key to understanding this verse and the verses that follow. In his commentary on the Gita, Yogananda taught that Om (Aum) is the Cosmic Vibration — what modern science calls the background hum of the universe, what mystics of all traditions have called the primordial Word or Logos. To chant Om is not merely to recite a syllable but to align one's consciousness with the vibrational ground of all existence. Tat — 'That' — Yogananda connected to the experience of transcendence in deep meditation, where the individual awareness dissolves into an incomprehensible vastness that can only be gestured at with a pronoun. Sat is the recognition that only Brahman truly is — all appearances are waves on this Ocean. The great traditions of India, Yogananda taught, were not superstitions but systematic sciences for realizing Om Tat Sat directly.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka emphasizes that this verse establishes the cosmic foundation of all dharmic action. The three syllables are not merely names but express the essential nature of Brahman in its three aspects: Om = Brahman as the all-pervading vibratory presence behind creation; Tat = Brahman as the Transcendent beyond all qualities and forms; Sat = Brahman as the Eternal Being who is always present and real. The verse makes a startling ontological claim: brāhmaṇās tena vihitāḥ purā — the brahmins themselves, the Vedas themselves, the yajñas themselves were established by and from this Reality. Sacred tradition is not a human construction; it is an emanation of Brahman expressing itself through these three syllables. This is why all Vedic acts are initiated with Om — they are returning to their own source.

verses.sanskrit: तस्माद् ॐ इत्य् उदाहृत्य यज्ञ-दान-तपः-क्रियाः । प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्म-वादिनाम् ॥
verses.transliteration: tasmād om ity udāhṛtya yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ | pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṃ brahma-vādinām ||
verses.translation: Therefore, with "Om" uttered (om ity udāhṛtya), the acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity prescribed by the scriptures (vidhānoktāḥ) are always begun by the knowers of Brahman (brahma-vādinām).

word_breakdown.meaning: therefore, for this reason — because Om Tat Sat is the designation of Brahman
having said 'Om'; with the utterance of Om
having uttered, having pronounced; after invoking
the acts of sacrifice (yajña), charity (dāna), and austerity (tapas)
are begun, are set in motion, proceed
prescribed by scriptural injunction (vidhāna); as laid down in the Vedas
of the knowers of Brahman; of those who speak and follow the path of Brahman (brahma-vādinām, genitive plural)

commentary.dadaji: The practical teaching follows naturally from verse 23: since Om is the primordial syllable through which Brahman established all sacred tradition, every act of sacred tradition should begin with Om. This is not ritualism — it is a conscious anchoring of action in its source. The brahma-vādins, those who truly understand and speak Brahman, know this. They do not begin sacrifice, charity, or austerity as isolated human deeds; they begin them as offerings returned to the very Reality from which they came. Satatam — always — tells us this is not occasional practice but the orientation of every sacred act without exception. Om as the opening syllable is the reminder: this is not mine; this flows from and toward Brahman.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda would connect this verse to the Vedic tradition of pūrva-pakṣa — the invocatory opening. Every Vedic ritual begins with Om because Om sanctifies by rooting the action in the Absolute. The brahma-vādinām — those whose speech and life are oriented toward Brahman — understand this not as mere convention but as ontological reality. When Om is uttered with awareness, the practitioner steps out of personal ego-space and into cosmic sacred space. Vidhānoktāḥ reminds us that this is not self-invented spirituality but a transmitted science, received from the guru-lineage and the Vedic revelation. Sacred action without Om risks remaining at the level of human will rather than divine offering.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda would teach this verse as a practice instruction. He often guided disciples to inwardly chant Om before meditation, before service, before any spiritual act. The reason is physiological and spiritual simultaneously: Om vibrates in the spinal center (medulla oblongata) and resonates with the Cosmic AUM. To begin with Om is to tune the instrument of the body-mind to the cosmic frequency before playing the music of sacred action. Brahma-vādinām — knowers of Brahman — are those who have moved from intellectual understanding of these principles into direct experience. Their every act becomes a continuous yajna, an unbroken offering, precisely because they never lose the thread of Om.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka explains this verse as providing a concrete śāstric instruction: Om must precede all three sacred activities — yajña (sacrifice), dāna (charity), tapas (austerity). This is vidhāna, scriptural regulation, not mere suggestion. The Gita is confirming the Vedic tradition rather than superseding it. Brahma-vādinām literally means 'those whose speech belongs to Brahman' — people whose words, thoughts, and actions are permeated with the awareness of the Absolute. For such persons, uttering Om before any sacred act is as natural as breathing. Satatam — the word 'always' — tells us that there is no sacred act so small or so familiar that it can be begun without this anchoring in the Absolute.

verses.sanskrit: तद् इत्य् अनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञ-तपः-क्रियाः । दान-क्रियाश् च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्ष-काङ्क्षिभिः ॥
verses.transliteration: tad ity anabhisandhāya phalaṃ yajña-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ | dāna-kriyāś ca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ ||
verses.translation: "Tat" (That) — without aiming at fruit (anabhisandhāya phalam), various acts of sacrifice, austerity, and the diverse acts of charity are performed by those who desire liberation (mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: with (the word) 'Tat'; dedicating to 'That' — the Transcendent Absolute
without aiming at, without fixing the mind upon; not targeting as a goal
the acts of sacrifice (yajña) and austerity (tapas)
the acts of charity, the various forms of giving
are performed, are done, are carried out
by those who long for liberation; by the seekers of mokṣa (freedom from the cycle of birth and death)

commentary.dadaji: The second syllable, Tat, transforms the inner architecture of action. While Om roots action in Brahman's being, Tat orients the action toward the Transcendent by releasing attachment to results. Anabhisandhāya phalam — without fixing one's aim on the fruit — is the teaching of nishkāma karma brought to its highest expression. The practitioner says inwardly: 'This act is not mine and its fruit is not for me — it belongs to That, the Nameless.' Mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ identifies who naturally lives in this way: those who genuinely long for liberation. When the heart is oriented toward freedom, it naturally loosens its grip on the fruits of action, because it has glimpsed a goal so much greater that ordinary rewards lose their pull.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Swami Sarvapriyananda would connect anabhisandhāya phalam directly to the teaching of Chapter 3 (nishkāma karma) and Chapter 12 (the characteristics of the dear devotee). 'Tat' as the orienting syllable is a practical tool of surrender: by mentally invoking 'Tat' before and during action, the practitioner shifts the grammatical subject — the doer — from 'I' to 'That'. The action happens, the fruit unfolds, but the ego has stepped aside. This is not passivity or indifference; it is the highest form of engagement — complete action without psychological ownership of results. Mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ tells us this is not for those still entangled in worldly ambition, but for those whose deepest longing is freedom itself.
commentary.yogananda: Yogananda would point out that 'Tat' — 'That' — is the syllable of pure transcendence. It gestures at what cannot be named: the Absolute beyond all qualities. To dedicate action to 'That' is to offer it to the Unknown, the Uncontainable — which is the deepest possible act of faith. Yogananda taught that the liberation-seeker (mokṣa-kāṅkṣin) is not someone who has suppressed desire but someone whose desire has been purified into a single flame directed at God. All other desires become uninteresting by comparison. From this place of single-pointed longing, giving up the fruits of action is not a sacrifice but a natural overflow — you are already living in the freedom you seek.
commentary.goyandka: Pandit Goyandka explains that 'Tat' is the syllable of renunciation-in-action. The seeker of liberation does not renounce action — he performs various (vividhāḥ) acts of sacrifice, austerity, and charity. But the inner stance is transformed: anabhisandhāya phalam, not targeting the result. This is the teaching of karma-yoga at the level of the advanced sādhaka. The word vividhāḥ is important — it tells us the range of sacred acts remains wide and full; what changes is only the orientation. Tat as a prefix to action is a constant internal declaration: 'This is not for me; this is for That which is beyond me.' Such action leaves no karmic residue and progressively purifies the antaḥkaraṇa (inner instrument) toward liberation.

verses.sanskrit: सद्-भावे साधु-भावे च सद् इत्य् एतत् प्रयुज्यते । प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्-छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते ॥
verses.transliteration: sad-bhāve sādhu-bhāve ca sad ity etat prayujyate | praśaste karmaṇi tathā sac-chabdaḥ pārtha yujyate ||
verses.translation: In the sense of reality (sad-bhāve) and in the sense of goodness (sādhu-bhāve), the word "Sat" is employed (prayujyate), O Pārtha; and likewise the word "Sat" is applied to auspicious and praiseworthy actions (praśaste karmaṇi).

word_breakdown.meaning: in the sense of being, existence, reality; when denoting that which truly is
in the sense of goodness, virtue, excellence; when referring to what is noble and worthy
is used, is employed, is applied
in action, in deed, in sacred activity
the word Sat; the syllable Sat
O son of Pṛthā (Arjuna); an address to Arjuna
is joined, is applied, is connected, is fitting
